subject: Re: Origin of fonts
msgSnippet: It seems that Jerome was the original Quickscript font. It is a senior font, with ligatures and is apparently supposed to join adjacent characters where
messageBody:
It seems that Jerome was the original Quickscript font. It is
a "senior" font, with ligatures and is apparently supposed to join
adjacent characters where appropriate.
Junior was a derivation of that, and provided some separation
between characters. This made the shapes easier to see and easier to
read for all us beginners.
The creator of these two fonts is apparently at
http://www.qsl.net/ws8g/index.htm

There have been complaints about the spacing information in these
fonts, for example in the excellent Shavian forum, when you highlight
or select the QS text, the spacing changes and becomes much closer.
(http://www.shavian.org/hugh/ikonboard/ikonboard.cgi)

In an attempt to combat this problem, I modified the Jerome font
and created the 'QSJ Block'. My primary reason was that I wanted to
play around with the Golden Ratio in font shapes, but I also wanted
to create something that might have fewer spacing problems. This is a
QuickScript Junior font, with intentional separations between
letters. It seems foolish to provide a font, no matter how 'junior',
without at least the ligatures specified by Read himself, so my font
does include them.
The Jerome and Junior fonts are provided free for all; since mine
is a derivation of Jerome, I can do no less.


--- In Read_Alphabet@y..., "andy_callaway" <acal@o...> wrote:
> Chaps -
>
> On my system, I have two fonts that appear to be Quikscript: QSJ
> Block Black, and junior. Does anyone know the origin of these two?
>
> Cheers, Andy
